bioghist.p: The urban designer, regional planner and educator, Percy Johnson-Marshall, was born in Ajmer, India, on 20 January 1915. He studied at Liverpool University School of Architecture, and began his career as a planner in 1936, working for a number local authorities: Middlesex County and Willesden Borough (1936-1938); Coventry City (1938-1941); Greater London Region (1948-1949); and, London County Council (1949-1959). He advised the Government of Burma on planning and reconstruction (1945-1946), and worked in Britain for the Ministry of Town and Country Planning (1948).

His career in higher education began in 1959 at the University of Edinburgh Department of Architecture, first as Senior Lecturer and then, in 1964, as Professor of Urban Design and Regional Planning with his own department within Sir Robert Matthew's School of the Built Environment (1967). He was a director of the Architecture Research Unit (1961-1964) and founder of the Planning Research Unit (PRU)(1962). The PRU was involved in the preparation of regional plans including those for the Lothians, Grangemouth-Falkirk, and the Scottish Borders.

In 1962, Percy Johnson-Marshall and Associates was launched with the commission as planning consultants to the University of Edinburgh for its Comprehensive Development Area. The practice was also involved in master plans for Sao Paulo, Porto, and Islamabad, reports for the Scottish Development Department, and various redevelopment schemes in UK towns such as Edinburgh, Kilmarnock and Salford. In 1966, Johnson-Marshall published Rebuilding cities.

scopecontent.p: The collection comprises a wide range of material connected with architecture and planning. This includes published books and journals, personal and professional papers, papers relating to various professional organisations, survey material, planning reports, government reports, plans, drawings, photographs and slides. There is also a large quantity of comparative material with major subject listings which include: Urban Design, Regional Planning, Town and Country Planning, Post-war Planning and Reconstruction, New Towns, Architecture, Urban History.

There is material relating to: University of Liverpool studentships, 1931-1938; Willesden Borough Council, 1930-1938; Coventry City Council, 1939-1959; London County Council, 1937-1968; World War II service in India and Burma, 1940-1956; Association of Building Technicians, 1940-1965; Service Arts and Technical Organization (SATO), 1943-1946; School of Planning and Research for National Development, 1946-1957; Ministry of Town and Country Planning, 1948; International Centre for Regional Planning and Development (ICRPD), 1955-1962; teaching duties at the University of Edinburgh, 1959-1988; Percy Johnson-Marshall and Associates, 1962-1985; United Nations; Ministry of Overseas Development; Association for Planning and Regional Reconstruction; Housing Centre Trust; International Society of City and Regional Planners (ISoCARP); Modern Architectural Research Group (MARG); Mars Group of the Congres Internationaux d'Architecture Moderne; Royal Institute of British Architects; Royal Town Planning Institute;Society for the Promotion of Urban Renewal (SPUR); and, the Commonwealth Human Ecology Council (CHEC).
There are also: collected books; collected journals; mixed correspondence and papers; and, a collection of slides.

arrangement.p: The Percy Johnson-Marshall Collection consists of approximately 20 subcollections. Material which has not yet been arranged and catalogued in detail has been listed to file level.

otherfindaid.p: There are 2 handlists available for browsing. The first covers material from Percy Johnson-Marshall's personal collection. The second covers material from the former Patrick Geddes Centre for Planning Studies at the Outlook Tower. It is possible to search and browse catalogued sub-collections, and to browse handlists of manuscripts and map holdings at www.johnson-marshall.lib.ed.ac.uk

relatedmaterial.p: Percy Johnson-Marshall owned around 8,500 books relating to architecture, and town and regional planning. He also collected nearly 800 journal titles, mostly relating to architecture, and town and regional planning, although some also relate to art and literature. The runs for these are mostly incomplete, and some are sporadic. The journal titles and editions available have been listed, as have the books, and all are available for searching.
At E2006.1 there is a seven page typescript (copy) of memories of Sir Stirrat Johnson-Marshall (1912-1981) written by Percy Johnson-Marshall in December 1981.
